column4: man ubuntu's frozen up like 3 times when ive tried to run a simple program
somethings up
and its not my hardware
wtf is happening to me?
6.10 is buggy
what program?
what video card and drivers?
that's old
such an old card with such an old driver may very well hve poor 3D support, and since it's loaded into the kernel, it could crash it
I mean that card is over 10 years old I think
are you sure that you can boot into Dapper and run the same program with the same driver and not crash?  (please use my nickname so I can find your lines)
no offense but if you don't type my nick then I'm not going to be able to follow this conversation very well
the same exact game works PERFECT in windows
ok, I understand.  But that's a different driver.  Again, are you sure Dapper works perfectly with it?
what version are you using now?
im using 6.10 now
and when did you run it on Dapper?
right before edgy came out
were you using the same video driver?
yes i was
what driver is that?
are there any errors in your syslogs or in ~/.xsession-errors ?
(gnome-panel:4444): Gtk-WARNING **: gtk_widget_size_allocate(): attempt to alloc
that's not an error actually, just a warning, and it isn't related to billiard-gl :)
could it be ubuntu doesnt like my hardware?
well, it could be a hardware problem.  If you really care, I suggest you file some bug reports.  :)
are there any 3d apps that don't freeze?
penguin racer doesnt freeze

and I know you said it works in Windows, but sometimes Linux handles hardware differently.  My motherboard has a strange IRQ issue that can cause Windows to bluescreen but Linux just boots on and makes a minor complaint
it does the opposite to me
all I know to suggest now (other than changing hardware) is to file some bug reports
ive filed bug reports before but never were fixed
where did you file them?
the apt repositories
um...like on what web site?
dont know a website
...by what method did you file a bug report then?  ...?
apt repos are not bug-reporting stations...
try www.launchpad.net :)  file some there
sounds like a hardware problem to me
it's not overclocked, is it?
is it overheating?
i dont overclock..could it be i need to reconfigure a kernel?
that shouldn't be necessary.  maybe it's just that Linux is a bit more stringent with your particular hardware.  again, all I can recommend is to file some bug reports on launchpad
what do i do if linux is more strigent with my ahrdware?
get different hardware, or ...file bug reports and help the devs fix the crashes
I understand...same here
i do art
I suggest you look in your syslogs for errors...maybe you can tweak something that's causing a problem
i dont know how to do that
sudo less /var/log/syslog, for starters...look at the different log files for things that might be hardware problems in the boot process
another possibility is to go to the Ubuntu forums and mailing lists and ask there...other folks might have more ideas
you might try Debian instead of Ubuntu...you never know
ive tried debian
try Debian again...it's updated often
testing
a rock

no offense, but if I could offer a suggestion?  :)  Leave this channel, post on the ubuntu forum and on the ubuntu-users list, and go to launchpad.net and file a bug report on billiard-gl and whatever other apps crash.  then wait patiently for answers :)
are you asking rhetorical questions now?
methinks you need to look inside yourself for the answers you need :)
try this: http://linuxfromscratch.org =)
that onez hard
maybez zo butz youz learnz lotz
if I don't hear from you in 5 minutes I'll call 911
so i have alot to learn about linux? so your'e sure it wouldnt be the kernel?
no, I'm not sure about anything.  I'm not even at your computer.  I can't help you any more, I'm afraid.  I've already told you my recommendations.  Now the rest is up to you.  :)
yes, I can't fix it for you, sorry :p
part of the fun is fixing it yourself.  I just spent 90 minutes getting fuzzyocr to work in SpamAssassin to filter out image spam.  now finally it works!
you shouldn't trust any system built by someone who says something like that :)
uh...no...it's a system of Perl modules...not binary stuff...not 3D stuff...not driver stuff...not kernel stuff...so no...not everything crashes, ok!?  :)
whoa!  why did you suddenly bring up ACPI??
well, you might try adding something to the kernel boot line...I recommend searching the Ubuntu wiki for info
now i disab;led acpi and billard-gl either just locks up and sends me back to gdm login
ok, check the logs for errors
why do you have PNP disabled?  and what kind of CPU do you have?
i have a p4
is pn p supposed to be enabled? i can reboot and enable it again in the bios
I dunno, try it if you want
like I said, look in the logs for errors...I already said that but you seem to ignore half of what I suggest :)
it now just locks up and sends me back to the login screen
something's probably segfaulting
how can i tell if it's from billard-gl
for the last time...look in the logs
are you using two computers?
ok, here's a problem...
most likely, when it crashes and restarts gdm, it clears out the ~/.xsession-errors file
ooh, ooh...look in the X log file
it looks like this is boiling down to what I said earlier...file a bug report!
you told me earlier that you didn't actually file a bug report
go to launchpad.net and FILE A BUG REPORT, please
sorry, but I'm through with this problem...my last words are, file a bug report.  there's nothing more we can do.
because people like you refuse to help by filing bug reports?
